name: Short-beaked Echidna
description: A spiny, nocturnal monotreme with a tube-like snout and powerful digging claws. It has no teeth and uses a long, sticky tongue to catch ants and termites.
image_alt: Short-beaked Echidna, photo: Zoo Prague archives
proportions: Body length 35–55 cm, tail 9 cm, weight 2.5–6 kg
reproduction: Gestation 9–27 days, lays one egg, which hatches after 10 days in the mother's pouch.
attractions: Solitary and nocturnal, it uses an excellent sense of smell to locate termite mounds, which it breaks open with strong claws. Its sticky tongue collects insects quickly. When threatened, it curls into a spiky ball or burrows rapidly.
breeding: Zoo Prague has kept echidnas since the 1950s. One individual, brought from Australia by Prof. Veselovský, lived for 50 years in our zoo.
